title_sort: charles h. harris to walt whitman, 30 may 1864
title: Charles H. Harris to Walt Whitman, 30 May 1864
text: Dear Uncle As i shal[shall] now clame[claim] you four[for] you remain as dear to me as mi[my] one [relation] Wal[Well] Uncle i[I] got home all lonely only i[I] was mity[mighty] tiard[tired] whin[when] i[I] arrived i[I] in Brattelboro but i[I] am fuly[fully] wal[well] Reasted[rested] now as four[for] mi[my] wound i[I] dont[don't] think it is as wal[well] as it was whin[when] i[I] left Washington but i[I] think it will be all rite after a while Charles Dunkler get home all rite also he sens his love to youOh Uncle i[I] wish you ware hear in old Vermont with me we wod[would] have some late old times fishing a mong[among] the green mountains that what master Wal[Well] Uncle i[I] soppose[suppose] that you like on the old court Register now as ever oh the boys must think a good deal of you i[I] wish i[I] had see you now i[I] most Pay the wine it seames[seems] lonesome hear without you but Nevr[never] mind i[I] woant[won't] be long before i[I] shal[shall] be whare[where] i[I] Can see you once mour[more] i[I] told mi[my] folks about you thay[they] think thr[the] soldier Boys out to think a grate Deal of youwhin[When]i[I]arived[arrived] in Brattleboro i[I] found mi folks all wal[well] i[I] tel[tell] you whot[what] theay[they] was very glat[glad] to se[see] mi[my] and also the Girlsâ€”oh Pleas giv[give] mi[my] love to Miss Howard and also to dear Carter also to Miss Gregg, wont youabout mi[my] Photograph i[I] will send it to you in mi[my] next letter Wal Uncle i[I] have no moare now to write this time Ples giv mi[my] love to all mi[my] [ac]quainize frinds[friends] i[I] will Close now by saying good By Dear Uncle wishing to hear from you son From year[your] Ever tru[true] young friendPles[Please] Excuse all mistakes an Bad Writing Also Excuse mi[my] shoart[short] letter this tim[time] an i[I] will try and Do Better in my next Charles H. Harris to Walt Whitman, 30 May 1864
